Comments_List: Design thinking, importance of vaccination, what works / does not work for technologies in the context of the developing world, how to develop a proposal and presentation for high-impact grants.
Learned how to think critically about creating new initiatives in the developing world and the pitfalls of technology.

Lots of student interaction and participation. Students get to develop and pitch their own project ideas to solve health issues in developing countries. No salient weaknesses. Anjelica Gonzalez was the best part of the course!!!

Strength: Taking on real-world challenge through Gates was excellent experience

Weakness: We should have the opportunity to apply for a Grand Challenge with the midterm and be able to work on it longer in the semester instead of having it at the end for the final.

It covered a broad range of topics, but I felt like it was very high-level and we could have dived deeper. It would have been great to learn more concrete frameworks that we can keep and apply with us moving forward. It also felt we were jumping around on topics rather than having a roadmap for how things connect from unit to unit.

Wonderful course! If you are at all interested in applying biotechnologies to the developing world, this is a great course to take. Even if you are not, Anjelica Gonzalez is one of the best instructors I have had at Yale and makes the course fun, interesting, and enjoyable.
Yes it is a great class, particularly for engineers, to think about the repercussions of technology development.
